title: Real Estate Judgement liens and other liens after chapter 7 bankruptcy.
question: Real Estate Judgement liens and other liens are not usually discharged after Chapter 7 bankruptcy. These liens can also attach themselves to future homes or property,that one purchases. Well after the judgement is place against them. My question is can these liens attach themselves, to cars that you have purchased , or a home that your purchased after filing for Chapter 7. As well as after the date the judgement was entered. Can they garnish wages etc. in order to collect on these liens after the person has filed for chapter 7.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Judgment lien,Debt,Lien,Bankruptcy and debt,Real estate and bankruptcy,Real estate
answers: Attorneys debate the effect of liens all of the time. They can be tricky. You can owe a debt that can be discharged in a Chapter 7 case, and yet a recorded lien can survive the discharge of the debtor. The lien can still attach to property, even though the debt that formed the basis of the lien has been discharged. Federal tax liens stay on real property for ten years, and cannot be avoided in bankruptcy through a motion. A Judicial lien can be avoided to the extent the lien impairs a debtor's exemptions. Non-possessory, nonpurchase money liens in personal property can also be avoided in bankruptcy court, but they are not filed for record. Creditors cannot take any action to collect debts that have been discharged in Chapter 7 cases, because that would violate a debtor's discharge injunction. If a debtor files a Chapter 7 though, and does not file a motion to avoid the judicial lien, the lien survives to encumber the property.
You should speak with a bankruptcy attorney. It appears you may be mistaken.

Chapter 7 discharges a debtor's personal liability on most types of debts including mortgage debts. A mortgage lien on real estate does not go away after bankruptcy, just the debtor's personal liability. So if the debtor stops paying the mortgage the mortgage company can foreclose their lien and get the property back but cannot collect against the debtor personally, as long as the debt was not reaffirmed.

Judicial liens are when unsecured creditors like a credit card company sues a debtor and gets a judgment and attached the judgment to any real estate owned by the debtor. Judicial liens that attach to a homestead can be avoided to the extent they impair a homestead exemption. If you had Judicial Liens on real estate that were not avoided in your bankruptcy the lien(s) will still be there but It would be a violation of the discharge for a creditor to attempt to attach a judicial lien on property acquired after a bankruptcy. Any attempt to collect a debt that was discharged is a violation of the discharge. So mortgage holder can only foreclose on the property but cannot collect on the debt against you personally by garnishing wages or attempting to place a lien on after acquired property.
Judgments are discharged in bankruptcy. The abstract attaches only to real property.
